TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed EllipseGeometry extends System.Windows.Media.Geometry
Public NotInheritable Class EllipseGeometry Inherits Geometry
public ref class EllipseGeometry sealed : System::Windows::Media::Geometry

Docs.summary: Represents the geometry of a circle or ellipse.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use the <xref:System.Windows.Media.EllipseGeometry> class with a <xref:System.Windows.Shapes.Path> element or a <xref:System.Windows.Media.GeometryDrawing> to draw an ellipse, or with the <xref:System.Windows.UIElement.Clip%2A> property of a <xref:System.Windows.UIElement> to define an elliptical clip region. The <xref:System.Windows.Media.EllipseGeometry> class also has many other uses. For more information about <xref:System.Windows.Media.EllipseGeometry>, see [Geometry Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/graphics-multimedia/geometry-overview.md).
## EllipseGeometry Compared to Ellipse The <xref:System.Windows.Shapes.Ellipse> class has a <xref:System.Windows.Shapes.Shape.Fill%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Shapes.Shape.Stroke%2A>, and other rendering properties that <xref:System.Windows.Media.EllipseGeometry> lacks. The <xref:System.Windows.Shapes.Ellipse> class is a <xref:System.Windows.FrameworkElement> and therefore participates in the layout system; it can be used as the content of any element that supports <xref:System.Windows.UIElement> children.
The <xref:System.Windows.Media.EllipseGeometry> class, on the other hand, simply defines the geometry of an ellipse, and cannot render itself. Because of its simplicity, it has a wider range of uses.
## Freezable Features An <xref:System.Windows.Media.EllipseGeometry> is a type of <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> object and therefore can be frozen to improve performance. For information about <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> features, such as freezing and cloning, see [Freezable Objects Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/advanced/freezable-objects-overview.md).
## Examples The following example uses two <xref:System.Windows.Media.EllipseGeometry> objects to define the contents of a <xref:System.Windows.Media.GeometryDrawing>. This example produces the following output:
![A GeometryDrawing of two ellipses](~/add/media/graphicsmm-geodraw.jpg "A GeometryDrawing of two ellipses") Two EllipseGeometry objects
[!code-csharp[DrawingMiscSnippets_snip#GeometryDrawingExampleWholePage](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/DrawingMiscSnippets_snip/CSharp/GeometryDrawingExample.cs#geometrydrawingexamplewholepage)] [!code-xaml[DrawingMiscSnippets_snip#GeometryDrawingExampleWholePage](~/samples/snippets/xaml/VS_Snippets_Wpf/DrawingMiscSnippets_snip/XAML/GeometryDrawingExample.xaml#geometrydrawingexamplewholepage)]

## Remarks This method is used to produce modifiable copies of frozen <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> objects (or any <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> object). For convenience, this method shadows the inherited version with a strongly typed implementation.
For more information, see <xref:System.Windows.Freezable.Clone%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType>.

public override double GetArea (double tolerance, System.Windows.Media.ToleranceType type);
.method public hidebysig virtual instance float64 GetArea(float64 tolerance, valuetype System.Windows.Media.ToleranceType type) cil managed
Public Overrides Function GetArea (tolerance As Double, type As ToleranceType) As Double
public: override double GetArea(double tolerance, System::Windows::Media::ToleranceType type);

Docs.param: The maximum bounds on the distance between points in the polygonal approximation of the geometry. Smaller values produce more accurate results but cause slower execution. If is less than .000001, .000001 is used instead.
One of the enumeration values, or , that specifies whether the tolerance factor is an absolute value or relative to the area of this geometry.
Docs.returns: The area of the filled region of this ellipse.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Some <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry> methods (such as <xref:System.Windows.Media.EllipseGeometry.GetArea%2A>) produce or use a polygonal approximation of the geometry. The tolerance factor specifies the maximum distance between points in this polygonal approximation. Smaller tolerance values produce better approximations, but they require more processing than an approximation with a large tolerance factor.
